Patch Set 2:

Changing vmadm to set the secflags is not the right way to go. There are various better options. Patrick and I discussed this and agree that setting the secflags during zone boot, based on the kernel version configured on the zone, makes the most sense. Can you add that to this CR?

This looks good. Once you hear back from Rich Lowe on Patrick's question I am happy. In regards to a debug build. there is no hard rule on doing both or not. Some developers never do a debug build and others only do a debug build. It's probably good to do both at first, just to see the difference.

Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 8:

I'm not really sure that holding the zone mutex across this entire function is the best approach since you're taking pidlock in the middle. This seems like it could really lock up a lot of the system. Have you considered moving the code at the end of the function up into the zone lock near the beginning, and then taking pidlock after you drop the zone lock?

Patch Set 8:

> I'm not really sure that holding the zone mutex across this entire
 > function is the best approach since you're taking pidlock in the
 > middle. This seems like it could really lock up a lot of the
 > system. Have you considered moving the code at the end of the
 > function up into the zone lock near the beginning, and then taking
 > pidlock after you drop the zone lock?

I think I need some guidance on which races are of concern. If the process secflag operations aren't completed with the zone lock held, there could be a race leading to the zone secflags showing no ASLR but the processes having it enabled (or vice versa)

Patch Set 8:

Holding the zone mutex across the entire function call doesn't do anything for you. While you are iterating the processes, some will be in the new state and others will be in the old state. That loop will never appear atomic. You want to hold the zone mutex to ensure that no matter how how you examine the zone's ASLR value, you get a consistent view, but you don't want to hold a mutex for longer than necessary, and you don't want to hold multiple mutexes at the same time if you don't have to.
I don't think this is necessary.  Does lint complain without it?
You're correct. This one was unneeded but the one on my other function at 7112 was necessary. I've removed this one and will push shortly
Given the expense of switching this value, it would be nice to see some logic here to avoid duplicate writes. (Skip the process walk if we're already in the desired state)
Done

It looks like on linux, randomize_vaspace has been default to 2 when building the kernel since commit 32a932332c8bad842804842eaf9651ad6268e637 in 2008. Before that it defaulted to 1 in the same way.
I checked Alpine Standard 3.5.0, Ubuntu 14.04, Ubuntu 16.04, Centos 6, and Centos 7. They all were set to 2, as far as I can tell due to the kernel default. None had entries in /etc/sysctl.conf (or anywhere else in /etc)
In addition I searched the source of systemd for references to randomize_vaspace, which did not turn anything up.

As a result, I believe this should be safe to integrate. I also believe SmartOS should default LX zones to having security-flags.default=aslr (at minimum), which will need to be done in smartos (vmapi?) as opposed to illumos-joyent
Please make the naming of this function consistent with its lxpr_write_ counterpart

I very much dislike the way this turned out.
The issue is that if I make it lxpr_read_sys_kernel_rand_vaspace (I'm just noticing I typo'd the x to an s), line 847 will be over the 80 character limit.

So should I change lxpr_write_sys_kernel_rand_vaspace to lxpr_write_sys_kernel_rand_va?
I think the comment notation you used at L988 is a decent way to solve that issue.  Regarding the name choice, I would lean toward lxpr_write_sys_kernel_rand_vaspace, but it's up to you.
Done

Rather than have this logic nearly duplicated for the set/clear cases, perhaps consolidate it down to a single block (maybe a separate helper function) which accomplishes the desired task of changing the ASLR secflags state for the zone and its processes.
Done
change this to "is"?
Done. I went with "has been" which seems most natural to me

While p_lock synchronizes access to the per-process secflags, we don't appear to have an analog for those which belong to the zone.  This isn't a surprise given that they are not expected to change in value after startup.  Regardless, we should probably use some lock to synchronize access.  It might be worth querying richlowe about his thoughts on the matter.
I will be reaching out to richlowe. I'm going to go ahead and address the other comments so he will be able to evaluate the most complete version of the code.
This should always be true given the preceding tests will bail out if changes aren't required.
Done
this assert is unnecessary and also would result in an error if you build this using DEBUG, since lxzd is undefined. You should probably build and test a DEBUG platform

Thanks for bringing this to my attention. I wasn't aware these were ifdef'd out on release builds. I will make sure to build debug from now on.

Is it useful to build both release and debug, or should I just build debug from now on?
Real Linuxâ„¢ appears to accept other values.  Returning EINVAL here is probably fine, but it might be worth noting the discrepancy in a comment.

It looks like Linux specifically accepts any signed 32-bit integer. Most places in the code just check to see that it is non-zero. I've added the comment. I think that may be better than actually accepting any value in case the other ones are given special significance later.

I don't think the zone mutex is really doing what you want here since you are dropping that before you use/change the value and then you reacquire it later at the end of the file. It would be better to consolidate all of this logic while you hold the mutex to prevent races, although I am not sure if a race in this case will actually cause a bug.
Done
